description: Perhaps from Middle English blot, blout (“soft; flexible; pliable”), from Old Norse blautr (“soft”), akin to Danish blød, Dutch bloot (“nude”) and German bloß (“nude”).

adjectives.description: bloat (comparative more bloat, superlative most bloat)

entries.meaning: Distention of the abdomen from death.
(veterinary medicine) Pathological overdistention of rumen with gas in a ruminant.
(figurative) Wasteful use of space or other resources.
examples: Adding an e-mail feature to this simple text editor would be pointless bloat.

entries.meaning: (derogatory, slang, dated) A worthless, dissipated fellow.

verbs.description: bloat (third-person singular simple present bloats, present participle bloating, simple past and past participle bloated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, veterinary medicine) To get an overdistended rumen, talking of a ruminant.
To fill soft substance with gas, water, etc.; to cause to swell.
(intransitive) To become distended; to swell up.
examples: if a Person of a firm Conſtitution begins to bloat, and from being warm grows cold, his Fibres grow weak, Anxiety and Palpitations of the Heart are a ſign of weak Fibres

entries.meaning: To fill with vanity or conceit.
examples: Encourage him, and bloat him up with Praise

entries.meaning: To preserve by slightly salting and lightly smoking.
To increase to an excessive amount.
